The Truth About Homework
 
 Needless Assignments Persist Because of Widespread Misconceptions About Learning
 
 By Alfie Kohn
 
 
 
 There's something perversely fascinating about educational policies that are clearly at odds with the available data. Huge schools are still being built even though we know that students tend to fare better in smaller places that lend themselves to the creation of democratic caring communities. Many children who are failed by the academic status quo are forced to repeat a grade even though research shows that this is just about the worst course of action for them. Homework continues to be assigned - in ever greater quantities - despite the absence of evidence that it's necessary or even helpful in most cases.
 
 The dimensions of that last disparity weren't clear to me until I began sifting through the research for a new book. To begin with, I discovered that decades of investigation have failed to turn up any evidence that homework is beneficial for students in elementary school. Even if you regard standardized test results as a useful measure, homework (some versus none, or more versus less) isn't even correlated with higher scores at these ages. The only effect that does show up is more negative attitudes on the part of students who get more assignments.
 
 In high school, some studies do find a correlation between homework and test scores (or grades), but it's usually fairly small and it has a tendency to disappear when more sophisticated statistical controls are applied. Moreover, there's no evidence that higher achievement is due to the homework even when an association does appear. It isn't hard to think of other explanations for why successful students might be in classrooms where more homework is assigned - or why they might spend more time on it than their peers do.
 
 The results of national and international exams raise further doubts. One of many examples is an analysis of 1994 and 1999 Trends in Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS) data from 50 countries. Researchers David Baker and Gerald Letendre were scarcely able to conceal their surprise when they published their results last year: "Not only did we fail to find any positive relationships," but "the overall correlations between national average student achievement and national averages in [amount of homework assigned] are all negative."
 
 Finally, there isn't a shred of evidence to support the widely accepted assumption that homework yields nonacademic benefits for students of any age. The idea that homework teaches good work habits or develops positive character traits (such as self-discipline and independence) could be described as an urban myth except for the fact that it's taken seriously in suburban and rural areas, too.
 
 In short, regardless of one's criteria, there is no reason to think that most students would be at any sort of disadvantage if homework were sharply reduced or even eliminated. Nevertheless, the overwhelming majority of American schools - elementary and secondary, public and private - continue to require their students to work a second shift by bringing academic assignments home. Not only is this requirement accepted uncritically, but the amount of homework is growing, particularly in the early grades. A large, long-term national survey found that the proportion of six- to-eight-year-old children who reported having homework on a given day had climbed from 34 percent in 1981 to 58 percent in 1997 - and the weekly time spent studying at home more than doubled.
 
 Sandra Hofferth of the University of Maryland, one of the authors of that study, has just released an update based on 2002 data. Now the proportion of young children who had homework on a specific day jumped to 64 percent, and the amount of time they spent on it climbed by another third. The irony here is painful because with younger children the evidence to justify homework isn't merely dubious - it's nonexistent.
 
 *
 
 So why do we do something where the cons (stress, frustration, family conflict, loss of time for other activities, a possible diminution of interest in learning) so clearly outweigh the pros? Possible reasons include a lack of respect for research, a lack of respect for children (implicit in a determination to keep them busy after school), a reluctance to question existing practices, and the top-down pressures to teach more stuff faster in order to pump up test scores so we can chant "We're number one!"
 
 All these explanations are plausible, but I think there's also something else responsible for our continuing to feed children this latter-day cod-liver oil. Because many of us believe it's just common sense that homework would provide academic benefits, we tend to shrug off the failure to find any such benefits. In turn, our belief that homework ought to help is based on some fundamental misunderstandings about learning.
 
 Consider the assumption that homework should be beneficial just because it gives students more time to master a topic or skill. (Plenty of pundits rely on this premise when they call for extending the school day or year. Indeed, homework can be seen as a way of prolonging the school day on the cheap.) Unfortunately, this reasoning turns out to be woefully simplistic. Back "when experimental psychologists mainly studied words and nonsense syllables, it was thought that learning inevitably depended upon time," reading researcher Richard C. Anderson and his colleagues explain. But "subsequent research suggests that this belief is false."
 
 The statement "People need time to learn things" is true, of course, but it doesn't tell us much of practical value. On the other hand, the assertion "More time usually leads to better learning" is considerably more interesting. It's also demonstrably untrue, however, because there are enough cases where more time doesn't lead to better learning.
 
 In fact, more hours are least likely to produce better outcomes when understanding or creativity is involved. Anderson and his associates found that when children are taught to read by focusing on the meaning of the text (rather than primarily on phonetic skills), their learning does "not depend on amount of instructional time." In math, too, as another group of researchers discovered, time on task is directly correlated to achievement only if both the activity and the outcome measure are focused on rote recall as opposed to problem solving.
 
 Carole Ames of Michigan State University points out that it isn't "quantitative changes in behavior" - such as requiring students to spend more hours in front of books or worksheets - that help children learn better. Rather, it's "qualitative changes in the ways students view themselves in relation to the task, engage in the process of learning, and then respond to the learning activities and situation." In turn, these attitudes and responses emerge from the way teachers think about learning and, as a result, how they organize their classrooms. Assigning homework is unlikely to have a positive effect on any of these variables. We might say that education is less about how much the teacher covers than about what students can be helped to discover - and more time won't help to bring about that shift.
 
 Alongside an overemphasis on time is the widely held belief that homework "reinforces" the skills that students have learned - or, rather, have been taught -- in class. But what exactly does this mean? It wouldn't make sense to say "Keep practicing until you understand" because practicing doesn't create understanding - just as giving kids a deadline doesn't teach time-management skills. What might make sense is to say "Keep practicing until what you're doing becomes automatic." But what kinds of proficiencies lend themselves to this sort of improvement?
 
 The answer is behavioral responses. Expertise in tennis requires lots of practice; it's hard to improve your swing without spending a lot of time on the court. But to cite an example like that to justify homework is an example of what philosophers call begging the question. It assumes precisely what has to be proved, which is that intellectual pursuits are like tennis.
 
 The assumption that they are analogous derives from behaviorism, which is the source of the verb "reinforce" as well as the basis of an attenuated view of learning. In the 1920s and '30s, when John B. Watson was formulating his theory that would come to dominate education, a much less famous researcher named William Brownell was challenging the drill-and-practice approach to mathematics that had already taken root. "If one is to be successful in quantitative thinking, one needs a fund of meanings, not a myriad of 'automatic responses,'" he wrote. "Drill does not develop meanings. Repetition does not lead to understandings." In fact, if "arithmetic becomes meaningful, it becomes so in spite of drill."
 
 Brownell's insights have been enriched by a long line of research demonstrating that the behaviorist model is, if you'll excuse the expression, deeply superficial. People spend their lives actively constructing theories about how the world works, and then reconstructing them in light of new evidence. Lots of practice can help some students get better at remembering an answer, but not to get better at - or even accustomed to -- thinking. And even when they do acquire an academic skill through practice, the way they acquire it should give us pause. As psychologist Ellen Langer has shown, "When we drill ourselves in a certain skill so that it becomes second nature," we may come to perform that skill "mindlessly," locking us into patterns and procedures that are less than ideal. 
 
 But even if practice is sometimes useful, we're not entitled to conclude that homework of this type works for most students. It isn't of any use for those who don't understand what they're doing. Such homework makes them feel stupid; gets them accustomed to doing things the wrong way (because what's really "reinforced" are mistaken assumptions); and teaches them to conceal what they don't know. At the same time, other students in the same class already have the skill down cold, so further practice for them is a waste of time. You've got some kids, then, who don't need the practice and others who can't use it.
 
 Furthermore, even if practice was helpful for most students, that doesn't mean they need to do it at home. In my research I found a number of superb teachers (at different grade levels and with diverse instructional styles) who rarely, if ever, found it necessary to assign homework. Some not only didn't feel a need to make students read, write, or do math at home; they preferred to have students do these things during class where it was possible to observe, guide, and discuss.
 
 Finally, any theoretical benefit of practice homework must be weighed against the effect it has on students' interest in learning. If slogging through worksheets dampens one's desire to read or think, surely that wouldn't be worth an incremental improvement in skills. And when an activity feels like drudgery, the quality of learning tends to suffer, too. That so many children regard homework as something to finish as quickly as possible - or even as a significant source of stress -- helps to explain why it appears not to offer any academic advantage even for those who obediently sit down and complete the tasks they've been assigned. All that research showing little value to homework may not be so surprising after all.
 
 Supporters of homework rarely look at things from the student's point of view, though; instead, kids are regarded as inert objects to be acted on: Make them practice and they'll get better. My argument isn't just that this viewpoint is disrespectful, or that it's a residue of an outdated stimulus-response psychology. I'm also suggesting it's counterproductive. Children cannot be made to acquire skills. They aren't vending machines such that we put in more homework and get out more learning.
 
 But just such misconceptions are pervasive in all sorts of neighborhoods, and they're held by parents, teachers, and researchers alike. It's these beliefs that make it so hard even to question the policy of assigning regular homework. We can be shown the paucity of supporting evidence and it won't have any impact if we're wedded to folk wisdom ("practice makes perfect"; more time equals better results). 
 
 On the other hand, the more we learn about learning, the more willing we may be to challenge the idea that homework has to be part of schooling.

Cahuella

Students wouldn't feel overworked if they managed to budget their time more effectively. The average volume of homework being assigned in the United States is increasing, but it is by no means unmanageable by students who plan ahead. I find my classmates struggle with their homework because they're attempting to do more than they can handle. This is likely attributable to my location more than anything, but school sports take up more time than homework. My school's soccer or hockey team may not return home until 7 or 8pm after an hour long trip, a match, and an hour long return. Homework on the other hand does not require four or five hours of work a night if uninterrupted and if longer assignments are spread out over the course of the week. If high school students feel they are too busy to complete homework for all their classes, they may do better to drop other activities or take less demanding courses.
 
 That is not to say I agree with teachers assigning large amounts of homework, I am merely trying to show that homework does not take up extensive amounts of time, most students simply prioritize other activities thus decreasing the amount of time they can allocate for homework. High school students are not overworked. I am taking four weighted courses this semester, three of which are AP classes I've been taking since the beginning of the year. I receive a significant amount of homework each night compared to my classmates, but because I've prioritized my homework and studying over other activities, I've encountered no problems keeping up with homework or the class. I play golf by myself to avoid unnecessarily long team trips and still have plenty of time left over for on-line activities and teaching myself Korean. To suggest the work unmanageable is ludicrous, I think it would be more accurate to say that many students choose not to manage their homework as effectively as they could if they considered it a priority.
 
 I value homework as it increases my ability to learn the material. I find I get more out of spending half an hour on calculus work than taking the actual class. In the classroom one learns, homework is a way in which to encourage practice and more efficiently drill concepts and equations into one's head. The class is necessary for providing the means to tackle the equations, but unless more time can be provided for practice in school, homework is the best alternative for providing that opportunity, at least for people who learn better through experimentation and experience more than through listening to explanations.
 
 How beneficial homework is to the majority of students is easily debatable, but students who are focused on learning as much as they can through their work are less likely to encounter difficulty meetings their teacher's demands. Many people who may need to practice a new learned concept would not if it was not required, this is why homework is required. The idea is that it further cements new information into students' heads more effectively than leaving them to their own devices. I am biased because I find homework immensely useful to my learning, but a system in which students could further practice or learn information solely by their own accord would, for the majority, prove less beneficial than forced assignments related to the topic.
 
 
Also, has anyone else ever wondered why teens commit the highest number of suicides?
That could be due to a variety of reasons, from trouble adjusting to the demands of adulthood to severe harassment to the lack of acceptance for one's sexual orientation. I would be very interested in a study attempting to determine whether there is a correlation between large amounts of homework and teen suicide, but there are a huge number of factors which would need to be accounted for.

 I have to disagree with you again here. Let's examine the conditions you have set up: School grades are A, B, C, D, F. If it's the same as when I was in school, you can pass with anything other than an F. In a job, you either get fired or stay, which is a pass / fail system (or P / F). With school grades, you have an 80% chance of passing and a 20% chance of failing. With a P/F system, you have a 50% of either passing or failing. So, how would the grading method with a higher chance of success and a lower chance of failure be more stressful?

While you will undoubtedly reap vast rewards later in life for your sacrifice today, I am sure that with time you will find that knowledge is its own reward. Tough courses are....tough, yet you chose to take them. Why? Not for the homework I gather. Do you expect to derive no boon from your efforts? You must recognize the value in these rigorous courses because you have elected to take them. This shows strength of character. Unfortunately, having taken on this self imposed yoke, you are curiously vocal about the difficulties inherent in your chosen path. This protestation negates the sympathy one might have in your plight. If you want big muscles, lift weights, but if you lift the weights, don't sing me a song about how heavy they are. 
 
 Setting out one a journey of success such as you have done is difficult. It is much easier to take rank with the average than to set the bar higher, but no hero ever succeeded without leaving the village. No story worthy of being told involved those who did not suffer much in hopes of achieving much. When one goes on prattling about trials and tribulations or singing the praises of one's own accomplishments, one diminishes the effect of same. Meanwhile, the quiet achiever who stands aside and lets his burdens or accomplishments speak for themselves is accorded a just measure of respect.
 
 So, as I've said, I will be thinking/working for 10-14 hours a day! So let me ask you E Mutz, how many hours a day do you work?
 
 There is working hard and there is working smart. If you take 10 hours to dig a ditch by hand and I dig one in 2 with a backhoe, you have not accomplished more, but rather less. I am not one to crow or complain but I can tell ye that my work load that I take on through willing pursuit of knowledge and through tasks put on me by my employer is at least comparable if not exceeding yours. Were ye to pester me further on the subject, I could go on in very exact and very boring detail.
 
 My point is not to say that ye do not have stress or that ye are not terribly busy. You seem to be an achiever and will doubtless be through all stages of your life. Other achievers see much of themselves in ye but cannot sympathize with the complaining as we have done what you have done and moved on to other struggles. Print a copy of your post, lock it in your yearbook. In 10 years, pull it out and give it a read. 
 
 Now that we have established that we are very busy individuals, how is it that we both have time for this subject?

post_info.post_title: Do you have a Type A- Personality?

Jo Bennett

I have to disagree with you again here. Let's examine the conditions you have set up: School grades are A, B, C, D, F. If it's the same as when I was in school, you can pass with anything other than an F. In a job, you either get fired or stay, which is a pass / fail system (or P / F). With school grades, you have an 80% chance of passing and a 20% chance of failing. With a P/F system, you have a 50% of either passing or failing. So, how would the grading method with a higher chance of success and a lower chance of failure be more stressful?

 
 Wrong, wrong, wrong. Just because there are 5 outcomes does not make them all equally likely. The only way it would do is if they were norm referenced to make sure 20% of students got each grade. Trying to assign numerical values to the chances of keeping a job is hard, it does not make any sense to claim that you have a 50% chance of losing a job. Apart from anything else, what sort of timescale are we talking about? I day? 1 year? 50 years?
 
 Apologies for the rant, trainee maths teacher, I had to stamp out this misconception with my year 8s this morning.
Shooterandproud

Can this really be happening to me? You're so good to me Lord!
 
 
 "First off, I do beleive that it has been said numerous times here that school is in session 6 hours a day, and not 5. We then have 2-3 hours of homework a night. We then have 4-6 hours of work."
 
 I never stated that you were in session five hours. In fact, I conceded that you were in class 7-5/6, a reference to your own assertion in post 2. Refer all the way back to my previous post, line 5. You will see that I granted you 11 hours of what you define as work. The 5 hour thinking block is a reference to post 8 which reads ..."When you're at school you are required to think for about 5 hours a day in a variety of different way on a wide variety of different topics." So there it is. Critical reading skills...
 
 
 "We have car payments! We have insurance payments! We have to pay for gas!" 
 
 Good heavens! I had no idea you had to pay for GAS!!!! Please let me know how I can sign up to sponsor you. You may be the most troubled soul I have met in my travels. 
 
 
 "We have angry teachers demanding we outline 30 pages of text on ancient China!(Yes, that's what I've been doing for the past hour). Work deadlines?! I guarantee you I have more due dates!" 
 
 China is a fascinating subject. I did a report on China in 6th grade. I got a B as I recall... As a senior scientist and technical writer, I am perhaps a poor individual for you to compare deadlines. Your deadlines affect grades. Mine affect dollars and lawyers, large lawyers with full briefcases and vacation homes that need to be paid for. The site assessment report I just shipped to the client was 35 pages, not including appendices. Every moment you invest in critical reading and writing will pay a dividend later in life. 
 
 
 "Stir in puberty, dating, and just growing up in general, and it makes for a hellish brew."
 
 This I grant ye doth suck majestically. Nothing compares to puberty, except perhaps hair loss...Fortunately, I have not had to deal with that delightful little blight of old age.
 
 
 "Now, lets get to the actual school work. For me, A- and below is failure. That is a 94% chance of failure 100% of the time. You had a 99.6% chance of failure, that lasted a max of one or two months. Now, my school work. Next year, I will be taking 3(Yes 3, as in 4.5 hours every other day) periods of math, one of which is a colledge course. I will be taking either Honors or AP(Colledge course) English. Honors or AP Chemistry. French 3, along with other required courses. So lets count 'em. I could be taking up to 3 colledge courses, when I'm 16 years old. You want to try that? This would raise my homework to probably 2-4 hours a day."
 
 Impressive indeed. You are setting yourself up for success in life. While you will undoubtedly reap vast rewards later in life for your sacrifice today, I am sure that with time you will find that knowledge is its own reward. Tough courses are....tough, yet you chose to take them. Why? Not for the homework I gather. Do you expect to derive no boon from your efforts? You must recognize the value in these rigorous courses because you have elected to take them. This shows strength of character. Unfortunately, having taken on this self imposed yoke, you are curiously vocal about the difficulties inherent in your chosen path. This protestation negates the sympathy one might have in your plight. If you want big muscles, lift weights, but if you lift the weights, don't sing me a song about how heavy they are. 
 
 Setting out one a journey of success such as you have done is difficult. It is much easier to take rank with the average than to set the bar higher, but no hero ever succeeded without leaving the village. No story worthy of being told involved those who did not suffer much in hopes of achieving much. When one goes on prattling about trials and tribulations or singing the praises of one's own accomplishments, one diminishes the effect of same. Meanwhile, the quiet achiever who stands aside and lets his burdens or accomplishments speak for themselves is accorded a just measure of respect.
 
 So, as I've said, I will be thinking/working for 10-14 hours a day! So let me ask you E Mutz, how many hours a day do you work?
 
 There is working hard and there is working smart. If you take 10 hours to dig a ditch by hand and I dig one in 2 with a backhoe, you have not accomplished more, but rather less. I am not one to crow or complain but I can tell ye that my work load that I take on through willing pursuit of knowledge and through tasks put on me by my employer is at least comparable if not exceeding yours. Were ye to pester me further on the subject, I could go on in very exact and very boring detail.
 
 My point is not to say that ye do not have stress or that ye are not terribly busy. You seem to be an achiever and will doubtless be through all stages of your life. Other achievers see much of themselves in ye but cannot sympathize with the complaining as we have done what you have done and moved on to other struggles. Print a copy of your post, lock it in your yearbook. In 10 years, pull it out and give it a read. 
 
 Now that we have established that we are very busy individuals, how is it that we both have time for this subject?

 
 I still agree with Rekhyt here. He's not saying that he has it worse than you, he is pointing out that life is stressful for everyone, adults don't have it better or worse than kids and vice versa. Most adults never dread going to work in the morning, they chose their job. Until college, we didn't, and we won't. We do dread going to school every morning, I don't know 1 kid that doesn't.
DrNo

I still agree with Rekhyt here. He's not saying that he has it worse than you, he is pointing out that life is stressful for everyone, adults don't have it better or worse than kids and vice versa. Most adults never dread going to work in the morning, they chose their job. Until college, we didn't, and we won't. We do dread going to school every morning, I don't know 1 kid that doesn't.

 
 Well, as I have said before, your level of stress is up to you. However, adults have many more responsibilities than kids do, thus their lives can certainly be considered more stressful (or at least there is more opportunity to be stressed). No offense, but you aren't an adult, and you haven't been out in the real world. Just because you choose a job doesn't mean you wake up every single morning and want to go to work. Either you are exaggerating by saying that every kid dreads going to scool every morning, or there are a lot of kids in need of a shrink. I mean, come on...what if there is some hot chick in one of your classes that you really like? You wouldn't be eager to go to school for that? That is really sad.
 
 I'd also like to add that a lot of your level of responsibility and/or stress is directly related to the choices you make. Generally speaking, you take on those responsibilities for some type of reward later on. This is why people who want to be successful strive to get good grades in school and take difficult classes. However, it isn't like it ends with good grades. Just because you get straight As in school doesn't mean you are just going to be handed a cake job and a fat paycheck without any type of effort. You will be working hard throughout your whole life, and the amount of responsibilities grow. Eventually, you will probably be faced with raising a kid (or kids) of your own. That alone is more responsibility than any student anywhere.
Rekhyt2238

Eventually, you will probably be faced with raising a kid (or kids) of your own. That alone is more responsibility than any student anywhere.

 
 I know plenty of people that have practically raised their siblings, because their parents are drunks, workaholics, et cetera.
Jo Bennett

Well, as I have said before, your level of stress is up to you. However, adults have many more responsibilities than kids do, thus their lives can certainly be considered more stressful (or at least there is more opportunity to be stressed). No offense, but you aren't an adult, and you haven't been out in the real world.

 
 Equally, you (I assume) aren't a child, and don't have any recent experience of what school is like. I have experience of both school and work, I know which I prefer, even when I've been taking any job I can to get money in.
AaronAlbrecht

"Oh, but we do! We have car payments! We have insurance payments! We have to pay for gas!" 
 
 
 
 
 i would like to point out we ( or at least i) dont get paid for school. with a job you get money, money to pay for the car payments, insurance payments, and gas which is a big deal for us kids, all we get is like the 5 dollars from our paper routes and if were like 3 years old an allowence. seems hard to pay for this stuff when your trying to save money for college and wakeing up at 6am to go to school and comeing back at 5pm. seems hard. i agree that adults also haev huge amounts of responsibilities. this "thread" or forum or w/e this thing is called is extremely pointless because its just abunch of people b1ch1ng about there hard lives.
Ignatius

We don't need no education
 We don't need no thought control
 No dark sarcasm in the classroom
 Teachers, leave those kids alone
 Hey, Teacher, leave those kids alone!
 All in all, you're just another brick in the wall
 All in all, you're just another brick in the wall
 
 ***
 
 Non abbiamo bisogno di educazione
 Non abbiamo bisogno di controllo del pensiero
 né di oscuro sarcasmo in aula
 Professore, lascia in pace quei ragazzi
 Hey, professore, lascia in pace quei ragazzi!
 Tutto sommato, è solo un altro mattone nel muro
 Tutto sommato, siete solo un altro mattone nel mur
 
 Pink Floyd, Another Brick in the wall (pt. 2)
huckleberry

I have to go with E_mutz on this. I work a 40 hour per week job. I also take home another 40 hours of work per week and return with it the following day. I have a mortgage to pay for and two cars. My wife does not work (an arrangement we mutually agreed on, we have no kids). I work the yard and the garden. I maintain the house and two vehicles. I also invest in the lives of those less fortunate than I.
 
 My reports are typically 40 to 50 pages per week. That on top of the ten to twenty 30 page contracts I must evaluate and write.
 
 I have seven people who report to me directly and I must review their work and assist and train them.
 
 I only WISH I could go back to school and not have to worry about groceries or bills of the generic kind. A car is a privelege. If you own one as a student, then you bet your a%% that you should be making the payments and insurance payments. You don't need one as it is covered. You want one and that stress is brought on your self. All stress is self imposed.
 
 This I guaranty: When you are our age and look back at this time, you will greatly desire to go back and time and be exactly where you are now.
 
 Huck.
csschwing

I'm currently training to be a maths teacher, and the main problem I see with homework is that generally if someone can do the work they don't need the extra practise, and if they can't then sending them home to get it wrong even more does nobody any good. There are other homework tasks than can be quite effective, such as writing instructions for how to undertake a method.

 
 tell me where you decided to work so I can spread the word emoticon_xbouncer
Shooterandproud

I have to go with E_mutz on this. I work a 40 hour per week job. I also take home another 40 hours of work per week and return with it the following day. I have a mortgage to pay for and two cars. My wife does not work (an arrangement we mutually agreed on, we have no kids). I work the yard and the garden. I maintain the house and two vehicles. I also invest in the lives of those less fortunate than I.
 
 My reports are typically 40 to 50 pages per week. That on top of the ten to twenty 30 page contracts I must evaluate and write.
 
 I have seven people who report to me directly and I must review their work and assist and train them.
 
 I only WISH I could go back to school and not have to worry about groceries or bills of the generic kind. A car is a privelege. If you own one as a student, then you bet your a%% that you should be making the payments and insurance payments. You don't need one as it is covered. You want one and that stress is brought on your self. All stress is self imposed.
 
 This I guaranty: When you are our age and look back at this time, you will greatly desire to go back and time and be exactly where you are now.
 
 Huck.

 
 I agree. Some adults are much stressed than the average teenager, just like some teenagers are much more stressed than the average adults. My problem comes with adults who claim they are much more stressed than the average teenager, and respond to any claim otherwise with "shut up and do your homework". Car payments, AP clases, and college prices ain't a walk in the park.
hollyh

I'm 25 and remember quiet vividly my not so former teenage years, i can say with the utmost certainty it is a period of my life that i would not want to re-visit. Yikes! Dont get me wrong, i actually quiet enjoyed high school, being a teenager however ... emotional roller coaster!
 
 My perception is not that teenagers are dealt a more stressful lifestyle, its simply that teenagers do not yet posses the maturity, hormonal stability and life experience to handle the stress. This is the problem.
 The overburdening of teenagers with what may simply be declared "normal" stress in an adult world is exasperated by the under developed psychological aspects of youth.
 
 6 years on and entering a law degree i believe i am far greater prepared to handle the enormous amounts of stress this academic venture will prevail. Its also undeniable this chapter will pose a far greater level of stress than any year of high-school.
 As an adult we have a far greater ability to delegate, deal and manage our stress. As a teenager it is simply trial and much error coined with the instability of our raging hormones.
 
 As someone mentioned earlier being a teenager majestically sucks! Does this mean its the most stressful period in a life cycle? no it does not, but it does suck more than the rest.
 
 On the topic at hand, yes there is far to much emphasis on homework in the academic system, especially elementary and high school years. One should not forget that social development is actually rated of far more importance in elementary years than academic success. Without proper social skills academia is futile. Helping teenagers to develop/encourage their own independent thirst for knowledge has far more benefit in the future than the forced instruction to do so.
Smallax

It looks to me that we are all looking in the wrong direction here. Addressing symptoms rather than the disease.
 
 We are all stressed in one way or another in whatever stage of life we find ourselves in. We shouldn't expect life to get easier , but that may be the only worthwhile goal we have to shoot for.
 
 If I want to die with the most toys - [so that I win!] - Then I need to expect to be driven like a dog all my life. Type A - Driven by my own expectations and desires. No one to blame but myself.
 
 Looking back at school, I have no desire to go back and did not want to relive it through my kids going there. I did however identify with the fellow that mentioned the fact of girls being there. :)
 
 I think its just a matter of perspective. You want to be rich or a straight A student, then deal with the stress. I made the choice to live a peaceful life, but I too am type-A. So I have to put all this stress back into perspective, on a regular basis. 
 
 I never did do homework though. My type-A revolved around girls and I was such a loser. Imagine the frustration there. :)
hollygirl

what i dont get is why do we have to go to school for 5 hours and thern come home and do more home work why dont we do it in class i meen i have 11 study halls a week and im only in 9th grade why dont we just have longer lessons and this way if we need the teachers help we can get it i think homem work is not nessacary at all in what way dose it benafit us. and sometimes i just sitt at home compleatly lost for like half an hour only to get in troble the next day for not doing it 
 how is this fair?
smiley

 how is this fair?

 Homework teaches you to work under your own initiative. You won't always have a teacher to quiz for your answers.
 
 And one other thing . . . you sit completely lost for half an hour. I used to get a couple of hours every night (which I do admit was pretty sh**ty).
 
 And why do you think you should not get into trouble for not doing as you were asked? You will be asked to do many things throughout your life that you don't feel like doing. It's only fair in that everyone will go through it, so get used to it.
Jo Bennett
I can only hope the homework hollygirl is receiving is from English...
peteratwar

Try Lessons Mon-Fri 09.30 to 17.00hrs. Break 1.5 hrs for lunch & 2 x 20 mins breaks (1 in morning & 1 in afternoos).
 
 Difference On Tuesday and Thurs was afternoon had compulsory sports.
 
 Sat morning lessons 09.00-12.00. Compulsory Sports in afternoon.
 
 Sun morning 2 hours compulsory lessons/Church attendance.
 
 Mon-Fri evenings 18.30 - 21.30 Compulsory homework 1 half hour break
 
 Sunday evening compulsory 2 hour homework
 
 Fortunately we weren't stressed as no-one had thought about it then to tell us we should be.
